If a small group of organisms (a small population) is separated from the main population, from which it originated (e.g., if they migrate over a mountain range or across a river, or if they settle on a new island, so that they cannot easily return), they will often find themselves in a different environment than before.

This new environment has different resources and different competitors, so that the new population needs different characteristics or adaptations to be a strong competitor, rather than what it needed before.
The original population has not changed at all. It still needs the same adaptations as before.
With time, the new population adapts to its new environment, and then it looks less and less like the other population.
After thousands or even millions of years two populations will look so different that they can no longer be classified as the same species.
We call this process speciation, which simply means the emergence of new species. Speciation is an inevitable consequence and a very important part of evolution.

Technological determinism is a term that encompasses a wide range of ideas in practice, from the technological push or the technological imperative to the strict sense that human destiny is determined by a logic that is linked to scientific laws and its manifestation in technology.

Most interpretations of technological determinism share two general views. On the one hand, that the development of technology follows a path that is largely outside the influence of cultural or political factors, and on the other hand, that technology itself has "effects" on societies that are more inherent than socially determined.
One could say that the automobile is unavoidably linked to the development of roads.
However, a nationwide road network for only a small number of cars is not economically viable. Therefore, new production methods are being developed to reduce the cost of car ownership.

The widespread ownership of automobiles also leads to a higher number of accidents on the roads, which in turn leads to the invention of new technologies in the field of medicine to repair damaged bodies.

After his farewell by Congress on July 4, a handwritten, signed by John Hancock and Charles Thomson, the president and secretary of Congress, was sent a few blocks away to the printing shop of John Dunlap.
During the night between 150 and 200 copies were made, which are now known as „Dunlap broadsides“.
The first public reading of the document was given by John Nixon in the Independence Hall courtyard on July 8.
One was sent to George Washington on July 6, which he read to his troops in New York on July 9. A copy reached London on August 10.
Of the 25 Dunlap broadsides that still exist, they are the oldest known copies of the document. The original handwritten document has not survived the passage of time.

KI (Künstliche Intelligenz) is often associated with Science Fiction, but is an important branch of computer science that deals with behavior, learning and the adaptation of machines to intelligent behavior.
Research in the field of AI includes the creation of machines to automate tasks that require intelligent behavior.
Examples of this are controlling, setting up strategies and time plans, the ability to answer customer questions and diagnoses, as well as handwriting, voice and face recognition.
Such things have become independent disciplines that focus on finding solutions to real life problems.

Today, KI systems are widely used in the fields of business, medicine, engineering and the military, and have also been incorporated into numerous software applications for home computers and video games.
Excursions are an important part of every school class. Not infrequently a teacher would like to take her students to places where a bus trip is not an option.
Virtual excursions are a technological solution. Students can view museum exhibits, visit an aquarium, or admire beautiful works of art from the classroom.
Sharing a virtual field trip is also a great way to reflect on a trip and share experiences with future classes.

For example, students at the Bennet School in North Carolina design a website every year about their trip to the state capital. The website is redesigned every year, but the previous versions remain online and serve as a scrapbook.

Blogs can also help to improve the writing skills of students. Although students at the beginning of their blogging experience often have a sloppy grammar and spelling, this usually changes when there is an audience.
As students are often a very critical audience, the blog author makes an effort to improve his writing style to avoid criticism.
Blogging "forces the students to learn more about the world around them." The need to inspire interest in the audience inspires the students to write intelligently and interestingly (Toto, 2004).
Blogging is a tool that inspires cooperation and encourages students to continue learning outside the traditional school day.

The appropriate use of blogs can enable students to become more analytical and critical; through the active reaction to Internet materials, students can define their positions in the context of the texts of other authors and express their own perspectives on certain topics. (Oravec, 2002)

Goma is a tourist town in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in the extreme east near Rwanda.

The Kruger National Park (KNP) is located in the northeast of South Africa. It borders in the east on Mozambique, in the north on Zimbabwe and in the south on the Crocodile River.
The park has an area of 19,500 km2 and is divided into 14 different ecosystems, each of which supports a different animal population.
He is one of the main attractions of South Africa and is regarded as the flagship of the South African National Parks (SANParks).
Like all South African national parks, the park charges daily entrance and conservation fees.

The Sundarbans are the largest mangrove forest in the world and stretch over 80 km from the Bangladeshi and Indian hinterland to the coast.
The Sundarbans were designated as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest within the Indian state is called the Sundarbans National Park.
The forests are not only mangrove swamps – they also include some of the last remaining stands of the mighty jungle that once covered the Ganges plain.
The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km2, of which a third is covered by water and marshes.
The Sundarbans are a nature reserve since 1966, and according to estimates there are now 400 Bengal tigers and about 30,000 spotted deer living there.

The Oyapock River Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River and connects the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges de l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
Their two towers are 83 meters high, their length is 378 meters and they have two lanes with a width of 3.50 meters.
The clearance under the bridge is 15 meters. The construction work was completed in August 2011, but the opening to traffic was not until March 2017.
The bridge is expected to be fully operational in September 2017. It is hoped that the Brazilian customs posts will be completed by then.
The Guaraní were the most important indigenous group that inhabited the eastern part of Paraguay. They lived as semi-nomadic hunters who also practiced subsistence agriculture.

The official currency of the Falkland Islands is the Falkland Pound (FKP), whose value is in line with the value of the British Pound (GBP).

Steigbügel are aids for the feet of riders, which hang down on both sides of the saddle.
